title: The ECB Is Taking Strong Action to Fix the Economy. Bonds Are Back in Fashion.
text:
Text size

Bond yields dropped around the world after the European Central Bank unveiled an ambitious stimulus package—including a bond-buying program—to stave off an economic slowdown.

The ECB cut its policy deposit rate by 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to -0.5%.

It said it would start buying €20 billion ($21.9 billion) of bonds monthly, starting Nov. 1. And notably, the central bank said it expects that program “to run for as long as necessary to reinforce the accommodative impact of its policy rates.”

Stock futures maintained their gains after the decision, with S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average futures both up 0.2%.

Yields of 10-year benchmark bonds in Germany dropped eight basis points to -0.64% after the news. The German economy has showed signs of a manufacturing-driven slowdown in recent months, which may have contributed to the ECB’s decision.

The benchmark U.S. 10-year Treasury yield fell as well, declining five basis points to 2.9%.

The biggest moves were in bonds of European countries with more stressed government-debt markets, however. The yield on Italy’s 10-year government bond fell 18 basis points to 0.79% after the news, and Portugal’s 10-year bond was down 12 basis points to 0.15%.

The euro slid against the U.S. dollar on the news, and was down 0.7% in morning trading as ECB President Mario Draghi spoke with the press about the decision. Gold’s spot price rose 1.6% to $1,521.35.

description: The European Central Bank unveiled a surprisingly ambitious stimulus package—including a bond-buying program—to stave off an economic slowdown. Bond yields fell on both sides of the Atlantic.
